content.creator:
bedtime company
January 11, 2025
content.content:
As is often said in moments like this, the finish is really just the start. And we say that not to be trivial as hell, but we‚Äôd like to pause and treat this as the finish for a moment, reflecting on the campaign: what we expected, how it unfolded, and everything we accomplished this month.
First of all, we prepared for this campaign for an incredible amount of time. A week before launch, we completely rewrote the text, prepared all the pictures, doublechecked everything, and then checked it all again as many times as we could. You can‚Äôt imagine how nerdy we can be about this stuff ‚Äî and we both love and hate that about ourselves at the same time.
Two weeks before the release, we started shooting this video:
We hoped it would come together in a take or two, but in reality, it took nearly two weeks of daily shooting and endless effort to piece it together.
It used to be proper working space
Preparation for this video began way back in the summer. Look at this rig we "invented" to shoot it!
To be completely honest, when the campaign launched, we were shocked to see the goal reached in under two hours. Yes, it‚Äôs not unheard of for Kickstarter campaigns, but we‚Äôre just two guys with no ad budget or media coverage. All we had at the start was 1,500 Instagram followers and 200 YouTube subscribers. Huge thanks to everyone who posted about us, liked, and shared‚Äîit made all the difference.
After the initial feedback, we realized we wanted to implement MIDI functionality immediately to showcase its potential. So, mid-campaign, we switched gears back into engineering mode and made it happen.
During the campaign, it was crucial for us to stay online and accessible for people across the globe. We kept in constant communication with you, answering emails, direct messages, and comments. It‚Äôs been amazing to connect with so many wonderful people who reached out to support us.
Of course, we also received our fair share of negative feedback. Some folks complained about the price being too high, and we tried to explain the realities of low-volume production. Others didn‚Äôt fully get the idea‚Äîand that‚Äôs totally fine. We didn‚Äôt create this to please everyone on the planet; we built it to bring our vision of a specific workflow to life.
We also had plenty of heated discussions between ourselves, which were necessary and productive.
Enough looking back ‚Äî let‚Äôs talk about the future!
Today, we‚Äôll rest. But starting tomorrow, we‚Äôll dive headfirst into logistics, sourcing, and tackling all the engineering hurdles ahead. This is the part we love the most. Don‚Äôt get us wrong‚Äîit‚Äôs been fantastic chatting with all of you and hearing your thoughts, and you‚Äôre always welcome to reach out with questions. But there‚Äôs something deeply satisfying about shifting focus from worrying about the campaign every minute to working on production and meeting deadlines. It‚Äôs hard to put into words.
Thank you for this incredible ride. Stay safe. If you‚Äôve backed us, don‚Äôt forget to check your emails. If not, we hope to intrigue you further‚Äîlet‚Äôs stay in touch!
Peace and love,
Igor and Kirill from Bedtime

comments.text: Congrats on the successful Kickstarter! I'm not exactly sure how I'll use this yet, but I will say that the MIDI feature is what pushed me over the edge to back the campaign. I've got a programmable MIDI pedalboard that I use for my FX pedal, and should be able to also hook into this for basic looping controls. Looking forward to seeing more videos of how to use it for different use cases, and very excited to get my hands on it when it's ready.

I loved my OP-1's workflow...it was the aspect of the 4-track tape that I missed most when I sold it but couldn't justify the cost to bring it back into my rig. I hoped a product like this would come to market as I couldn't engineer it myself and Norns was something I just didn't want to deal with. I couldn't have imagined this any more perfect than you two have. Thank you!

content.title: üéÑ Merry Christmas! An Important Update
content.creator:
IgorCollaborator
December 25, 2024
content.content:
Hi there! We hope you‚Äôre having a wonderful holiday season, spending time with friends and family. We‚Äôve been hard at work lately and have an exciting new feature showcase to share with you.
200 tape! units
First things first. The campaign has been running for two weeks now, and we‚Äôve raised almost 200% of our goal! From the beginning, we didn‚Äôt set an artificially low target to achieve the "10,000% funded" milestone - it‚Äôs a fun number indeed, but we‚Äôre not into those kinds of tricks. Our goal was clear: create 100 devices and move forward.
However, increasing the level of production would help us to cut some of the components costs, so we could invest more resources into developing features you (and weü§©) want, without raising final price!
Let‚Äôs make that happen! We are excited to introduce a stretch goal, and you‚Äôll love it!
But before we dive into that, let‚Äôs get back to the showcase. Over the past weeks, we‚Äôve been exploring various MIDI use cases, as robust and comprehensive MIDI implementation is a very important aspect of any musical gear. And we have to admit - it‚Äôs a game-changer.
While tape! remains a portable device you can take anywhere, MIDI integration now makes deeper connections with your studio setup and live rig possible.
üéπ <- -> üìº
Simply connect your tape! to your computer or any MIDI host, and you can control its parameters, set speed, start and stop tapeheads, synchronize loops with external sources, modulate it using Max/MSP or Pure Data, control tape! from your modular setup with a CV to MIDI converter and so on and so on. Possibilities are virtually endless. tape! is ready to support MIDI 2.0 and MPE.
Here‚Äôs a list of devices that can act as a MIDI host for tape! to name a few:
Any PC (Mac, Raspberry Pi, etc.)
Norns
Organelle
OP-1 Field, OP-Z
Push 3
Squarp Hermod
Kenton USB MIDI Host
And many more!
Check out our showcase video here:
Now, onto the stretch goal!
Currently, tape! cannot act as a MIDI host. It is a hardware limitation. So, we are setting a midi host stretch goal -  $200k. If we reach it, hardware and software will receive an upgrade to support it. 
Being a MIDI host adds a lot of new responsibilities to the device - from providing power over the USB cable when the connected device requires it, to dynamical parameters mapping - to support numerous amount of various midi controllers, available today. Just to scratch the surface.
Implementing this will require complex hardware upgrade and a lots of work on the software side as well.
Actually ü§ì MIDI host depends on USB host. Adding it would also open up various possibilities for connecting other external gear, yet we still gotta research that more closely! 
As a bonus, we‚Äôll also introduce a granular engine for tape!, expanding its sonic capabilities even further.
If you‚Äôre curious about devices that can act as MIDI hosts, this article is a great source of inspiration.
Thank you for your continued support, and let‚Äôs make tape! even better together! 
Merry Christmas! 
üåë
